posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: This is our first year using an electric solenoid. We are using the sealed linear solenoid at 12V. How do you control this in code? I can‚Äôt seem to find any examples of using this type of solenoid. We are using java. Solenoids are only used for unlocking our climb, motors are used to control our climb.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
What device are you using to electrically control it?  Spike, automation direct relay, PDH switched channel?

Edit: It‚Äôs not legal to use a PDH switched channel to control an actuator, see the post by Nuttyman54 below.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Create a PowerDistribution object and use the setSwitchableChannel function: PowerDistribution (WPILib API 2024.2.1)

posts.name: Nuttyman54
posts.cooked:
I don‚Äôt believe it is legal to control a solenoid from the PDH switchable channel per R504: image 935√ó163 16.7 KB

image 935√ó163 16.7 KB

image 935√ó163 16.7 KB

R501 defines electric solenoids as actuators.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Whoops!  You‚Äôre quite correct, I missed the ‚Äúnon-actuator‚Äù statement. @AlexT321 you will need to use one of the legal relay options instead of the PDH switched channel to control the solenoid.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Thank you! I will notify my mech team about this

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Legal relays don‚Äôt give you many options. There‚Äôs the automation direct relays or the old Spikes which are not something you can order.

Normal Arduino relays are not legal.

Spike H-Bridge Relay (P/N 217-0220 and SPIKE-RELAY-H), b. Automation Direct Relay (P/N AD-SSR6M12-DC-200D, AD-SSRM6M25-DC-200D, AD¬≠SSR6M40-DC-200D)

Instead of switching the power on and off from the PDH , my team used a VictorSPX motor controller (we had lots lying around from old tank drives) to control it. It gives a signal -12-12v and is pretty easy to control in the code.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Right now, we‚Äôre only using the solenoids to unlock our climb mechanism, so all we need is a way to give it power. We‚Äôre controlling the actual climb with motors. Are legal relays enough for that?

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: All depends how much force is needed to overcome the friction of the lock, but more than likely yes especially if it‚Äôs a larger solenoid. This year the wattage limit was increased so stronger ones are legal

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
Fake_Name131:

used a VictorSPX motor controller

I‚Äôll second this. May not be the most intended use of a Motor Controller, but it would allow you to control the solenoid via CAN rather than having to wire up the relay directly to the RIO. You‚Äôd just wire the solenoid to the output of the Motor Controller and use -1, 0, 1 as the ‚Äúspeeds‚Äù for an easy -12v, 0v, 12v across your solenoid. (You‚Äôd probably only need -1 if your solenoid isn‚Äôt some kind of spring-return or something)

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
Oh! I will also note that according to R505, you can power electric solenoids off the Pneumatics controllers. Though in this case, I don‚Äôt think it will supply enough current. Still good to know!

R505 *Don‚Äôt overload controllers. Each power regulating device may control electrical loads per Table 8-2. Unless otherwise noted, each power regulating device shall control 1 and only 1 electrical load.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Those can usually only output about 200 mA per channel.  This solenoid is 24W at 12V, so it will need about 2A.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked: Edited! Leaving it since its still good info for someone who potentially finds the thread in the future for a lower-power solenoid.
